newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico's Jalisco state subsidised 66,174 T sorghum.
newsitem.headline: Mexico's Jalisco state subsidised 66,174 T sorghum.

text.p: Mexico's Jalisco state has to date in the 1996-1997 crop cycle subsidised 66,174 tonnes of sorghum grown in the western state, the local government said.

Sorghum growers, who have struggled to sell locally grown feed this cycle because the federal government allowed imports over demand levels, have been partially subsidised in various Mexican states to ease pressures.

Jalisco's subsidy system offers growers compensation in terms of price and one-off payments to cover transport costs and debts. It is channeled through end-users and traders to encourage them to buy locally-grown sorghum.

Sorghum consumers are paying a floor price of at least 1,000 pesos per tonne, compared to market prices currently fluctuating between 800-850 pesos. They are also paying an extra 75 pesos per tonne of sorghum to cover growers' transport costs and to ease debt burdens.
The Jalisco state government then reimburses sorghum consumers. The state said it expected to pay out 4.96 million pesos in its dual subsidy system this cycle.
